awd_titl_txt: EarthCube Conceptual Design:  Enterprise Architecture for Transformative Research and Collaboration Across the Geosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
EarthCube design is a complex socio-technical systemof systems, in which communication between various domain subsystems and previously disconnected CI components,people and organizations enables more comprehensive, data-intensive research designs and knowledge sharing. The main features of project include an approach that:(1) follows and enhances existing patterns of data, information and knowledge exchange within and between geoscience domains, (2) integrates ?traditional? layered cyberinfrastructure components (e.g.information sources, catalogs, vocabularies, services, analysis and modeling tools) with CI components supporting scholarly communication, self-organization and social networking (e.g.research profiles, Q&A systems, annotations) and (3) supports continuous EarthCube architectural
evolution. The proposed work will be done in close collaboration with other EarthCube activities,taking input from a wide group of geoscientists and CI experts engaged in EarthCube, as well as information system architects from a range of academic and commercial projects.Design parameters include system abilities to: a) evolve by factoring in the impact of maturing movements like linked
data, ?big data?, and social collaborations; b) handle the volume, complexity and diversity of geoscience information; (b) incorporate new informational and analytical requirements, tools, and techniques,(c)accommodate different ideas and approaches to research and data stewardship;(d)make best use of NSFs current investment in the geoscience CI.

The innovative aspect of this architecture planning will include three component. It will be designed as a system of systems,i.e., the basic information objects and infrastructure of any community will be re-used, but will be modeled in a manner that higher-level operations(e.g., vocabulary mashup) can be performed on them. It will be based on emerging interchange practices and protocols for scholarly objects, a paradigm that will be designed to foster inter-community research collaboration and exchange. It will be centered on a social network of communicating scientists who will use the interchange protocols. The social network will consist of both people and the information objects they choose to share as they conduct research.

por.por_cntn:
The EarthCube GEAR (Geoscience Enterprise Architecture for Research) project addressed central challenges in the development of advanced cyberinfrastructure for geoscience research and education by offering a comprehensive conceptual design for EarthCube that leverages existing domain systems, responds to current and anticipated needs of the earth science community, and allows adaptation to emerging technical and social trends. The central distinguishing feature of the GEAR architecture, and the main intellectual contribution of the design, is a detailed exploration of the concept of a shared economy platform for matching available geoscience information resources with needs of geoscientists, and enabling resource compositions as mechanisms underlying the platform evolution. The key idea of this model is that the EarthCube federation of systems should support a marketplace for data, analysis tools, platforms and infrastructure elements, utilizing transaction and usage monitoring data, provenance documentation, and semantic exploration and matching to guide selection of technology products to meet research needs. A roadmap for rewiring the existing infrastructure components and establishing mechanisms for a new infrastructure based on a managed standards-based marketplace platform was presented. 

The project produced a comprehensive conceptual design report, and a series of supporting information products: an EarthCube Semantic Wiki designed to help EarthCube participants to converge on the meaning of key terms used across the initiative; a GEAR Information Model formally describing key design elements, which can be re-used for a more detailed architecture development; and a seed inventory of high-level information resources, including resources from EarthCube funded projects and pointers to key datasets, portals and software applications contributed by geoscientists in the course of EarthCube end-user workshops and surveys.

The key design notions have been validated through multiple presentations and workshops, and contributed to the development of EarthCube architecture. To support the conceptual design work, the project team analyzed geoscience user needs and research scenarios as expressed in earlier EarthCube roadmaps, workshop reports and other documents; conducted interviews and documented use cases; and synthesized user requirements for a novel system supporting cross-disciplinary geoscience research. The project team organized a Summit of Information System Architects, hosted several EarthCube-wide architecture meetings, and participated in the work of EarthCube Technology and Architecture Committee, its Architecture working group and other working groups. To get feedback from geoscientists, project results have been disseminated through a large number of professional conferences, EarthCube meetings and workshops. In addition, the project engaged several early career scientists and students, who were exposed to challenges of cross-domain data-intensive research in the geosciences through the compilation of use cases and development of supporting resource inventory.

This project’s primary impact, from the perspective of geosciences, is in the development of a conceptual framework, and respective information models and resources, to support efficient, scientifically-sound and sustainable resource sharing and collaboration across geoscience disciplines and stakeholders to address grand challenge problems in the Earth sciences. Efficient cyberinfrastructure underlying advanced geoscience research leads to better understanding of natural and human processes shaping the geosphere, which, in turn, improves the abilities of the society to address some of the key challenges faced by the world today, including climate change impacts, clean water availability, natural hazard prediction, efficient re-use of limited national resources, and enabling sustainable economic and social development. Our success in solving these challenges directly depends on better capacity for monitoring, analyzing and predicting the state of the planet, which can be achieved through better sharing of information resources and knowledge, as outlined in this conceptual design.
